lines.text: Well, what he can't do, it doesn't matter. It's the idea of Superman. Someone to believe in, someone to build a few hopes around. Whatever he can do, that's enough. I just wish that I could tell him that.
Lois, Clark is strong. And I'm not talking about how much he can bench press. He's strong where it counts, and when it counts.
Jimmy, give me back my dress.
Now there's something you don't hear around the newsroom everyday.
You took advantage of our privileged interview session to steal highly incriminating evidence from an unsuspecting subject... Oh! I love that! Mmmm!

[to Clark]
All right, maybe, somewhere very deep inside me is some eensy-weensy, microcosmic - although highly unlikely - possibility that I feel some sort of unmotivated, completely unrealistic attraction to you.
[talking about Lois]
Do you love her, son?
Yeah, I do.
Well, then tell her.
You know, people who love each other are supposed to be kind to each other.
Jimmy, I did not become editor of a major newspaper because I can yodel.
I only know how to make four things, and this is the only one without chocolate.
I win, you lose, we're both happy.
You know what's great about you?
Sure, but you could repeat it again.
Everything.
Oh please, I'll go to jail, I'll strap myself into the electric chair, just don't make me listen to this.
What in blazes is a Bobby Bigmouth?
[about his break up with Lois]
So what are you saying? That I should go crawling back on my hands and knees?
No, honey, fly back, it's faster.
What do I know? These glasses fooled me for two years. Oh boy, what a dope!
Even when a huge part of you didn't make any sense, there was a part deep down that did.
Yeah, well, just remember there's no perfect sunsets. There's a little crack in every cloud, but that's what gives you your silver lining.

And let's get something straight, I did not work my buns off to become an investigative reporter for the Daily Planet just to baby-sit some hack from Nowheresville! And another thing, you are not working with me, you are working for me. I call the shots, I ask the questions. You are low man - I am top banana and that's the way I like it, comprende?
You like to be on top. Got it.
Don't push me Kent, you are way out of your league.
So now tell me more about this woman you're going to Lex Luthor's ball with.
Lois is... well she's complicated. Domineering, uncompromising, pig headed... brilliant.
Does Superman have telepathic powers?

[blushing]
I hope not.
Clark, you can do the horizontal rhumba with the entire Met-Net cheerleading squad for all I care, just keep your hands off my copy.
Danger is my business.
I just wanted to say goodbye.
Goodbye? We're partners.
You don't need a partner Lois, you never did.
Well, maybe not, but I was starting to like having one.
Tell me the biggest secret you have.
What?
Tell me the biggest secret you have. Something you'd never reveal to anyone.
Why?
Because I'm about to tell you mine and I need blackmail material.
So you're saying you would never lie to your wife, that's assuming someone would actually be crazy enough to say "I do' to you?
I know you may not believe this, but there was a time where I had to be the best at everything.
You still think I'm crazy?
I think you're brilliant. But there is a fine line between brilliance and lunacy.
So, how did I rate as a date?
Oh, A-plus.
I hung on your arm decoratively.
You did.
Fawned appropriately.
Absolutely.
And just faded into the background during your big moment.
You were beautiful, yet invisible.
Mmm, make me go through another night like that, and I'll rip out your spleen.
The point is you are the same reporter you have always been. Hard-working. Dedicated. Maybe a little over the top sometimes. You could use some more vacations. Maybe a semblance of a life...
Is this leading anywhere?
Lois, you are the best reporter in the city. You always have been and you always will be.

Lois, if anyone knows what it's like to be on the outside, I do. Sometimes I feel like I'm out there fighting all alone. Sometimes I feel like giving up. But, then I remember that what I stand for is more important than anything else. Your work is important to the people of Metropolis. You're a brilliant, passionate journalist. Adversity has never stopped you before. Don't let it start now.
That's funny. Clark said the same thing.
I'm not surprised. Clark is a very smart guy.
Real nice kid, millionaire by the time he was your age.
Yeah, well I had the mumps in sixth grade, kind of slowed me down.
Well, that's a terrific reason to get married, to avoid harassment.
You know, it's true what they say - love stinks.
How could you see that from all the way over there?
I have a... really strong prescription.
I shouldn't have lost my temper.
Well, you're entitled to. I lose mine once every... what?
Three, four minutes.
Well, I like my quirks. I think they make me unique.
You certainly are unique.
People can have two sides to their personalities. Lois, believe me, I know.
[talking about Lois]
I worry when she gets that look in her eye.

I know our relationship has always been difficult to define, but, when I thought about how much I missed you, how much I was going to miss you for the rest of my life, well, I started to think, maybe there's more to our relationship than just friendship.
[seeing him asleep]
Or, maybe not.
What kind of person keeps a body frozen in a glass case?
Somebody who's having a hard time getting a date?
Well, you two are invited to my house for Christmas dinner tonight.
Well that sure beats the soup kitchen.
Don't get your hopes too high.
Clark! You came. Why aren't you in Smallville with your folks?
Oh, uh... my plane got snowed in.
It did? But it's not snowing... Oh! You are the best!
Here's some oatmeal if you want.
Did you make it?
Yeah. You probably don't believe that.
[he looks at the drippy oatmeal]
No, I believe it.
[talking about Superman]

Does he think that because he couldn't defeat some robot that that changes the way I feel about him? Clark, that's not what attracts me. It's his intelligence and caring. He's... he has integrity and an innate goodness. I mean, he's a lot like you.
We'll just put the word out on the street that we need a donor.
Emmet, we're scientists, we don't know anybody "on the street".
Lois, I want you to know that I think what you did for Clark showed incredible bravery.
It was nothing.
Was it?
I guess not. I guess there isn't anything I wouldn't do for him.
I like your new glasses.
Thanks.
Did you ever think of getting contacts?
No.
It's the not first time I've bent the law for a story, but I did feel bad because, after I finished rationalizing it, I realized that a big part of why I did it is because I don't like you.
Really? Oh, god, that is such a relief. I don't like you either.
Really?
Really.
Well, that makes me feel so much better. I couldn't stand the idea that I was just jealous because of Clark. It's so...
Petty. I know. I mean it feels so much better just to...
To just dislike you because... you're you.
[talking about Lois]
You know something CK? She's a class act.
I've always thought so.
Why wouldn't the Chief want us to tell Jimmy that he said that?
It's one of those father/son things.
Oh, really?
Sure, it's classic. Men are uncomfortable expressing their emotions directly. It's just like the father/daughter thing, only, when you finally do talk, you use more sports metaphors.
Ha, that's ridiculous.
[Perry sticks his head out of his office]

Clark, if Jimmy calls, tell him I know it feels like the bottom of the ninth with two outs and two strikes against him but that the Planet is gonna mount a full-court press, and we won't stop until it's game, set, match, Olsen.
Stop the presses! I've always wanted to say that in a newsroom.
Nobody ever says that, you know. It's just on television.
Well, sure, but it still felt good.
Uh, Lois, could you hand me a nail file?
Why do men always assume that women have nail files with them?
I'm sorry, but do you have a nail file?
Actually, I do, but only because it's part of my pocket knife.
[Clark tries to apologize after he just ran out on Lois. So she starts to mock him]

No, don't say a word. Allow me. "Lois, I can explain. I suddenly remembered that I had to get my mother's sister's poodle's hair cut, and so you can see why I had to leave you in the middle of our date with your thumb in your ear. But I'm sure you'll understand."
So basically what you're saying is, all my life I've attracted men that are controlling, incomplete, or downright liars because... because...
Keep going.
Because that's how I want to be treated? But if I want that kind of man, and I get that kind of man, why am I not happy?
You like chocolate, right?
How come everybody knows that?

But you know it's not good for you, and the older and wiser we get, the less tolerance we have for something that's not good for us. You're not a victim, Lois, so stop acting like one. You know who you want to be with, you've known all along. The problem is, he's just as scared as you are. So, who's going to be the first to step up and say the scary words?
How come you don't ask the simple questions?
I would... if I knew the easy answers.
He doesn't love you, Elise. You can tell when a man loves you by the way he treats you, by the way he looks at you, by the way...
Look, Ms. Lane, if you've found the perfect man, then I'm happy for you.
No, he's about as far from perfect as you get, but I'll tell you the difference between him and Calvin. I know that he wants my happiness more than his own.
Why I'm here, and how I can make a difference.

[Lois, Clark, Perry, Lex Luthor and Jack are all being held hostage in the Daily Planet building]
Jimmy... Jimmy, he could save us!
Ah, come on, Jimmy couldn't save baseball cards.
You see, Clark, there is no such thing as an invisible man.

[after Lois walks away, a bit sadly]
Yes, there is, Lois.

[Lois has witnessed a murder and has been receiving threats]
I do not need a bodyguard and even if I did, and I mean this in the nicest possible way, you would not be my first choice.
[walks away]

[smiles to himself realizing who her first choice would be]
Thank you. I take that as a compliment.
I still can't believe you came barreling in here like some 500-pound gorilla! If you really thought we were in trouble, why didn't you bring the police?
Look...
Don't tell me, I already know! You're like every other man in Metropolis! You've got this testosterone surplus that says, "I can do it myself"!
Lois, I've somehow managed to...
Mess everything up? No kidding!
Lois has a pair of Superman pajamas.
You saw Lois in her pajamas?
No! Well, yes, but it was an accident, when her robe came undone.
The name's Olsen, James Olsen.
We flip for the bed.
How about I get the bed, I lend you a pillow?
How about we alternate nights?
How about we don't.
Well, it's a big bed, how about we share?
How about we alternate nights?
Deal.
Kill or be killed.
Lois you're talking about war. This is journalism.
See, your problem is you think there's a difference.
You are really high maintenance, you know that?
But I'm worth it.
Well go ahead, I'm waiting.
For what?
The morality play, the "you should have trusted me and my infallible reporter's instinct' lecture.

Clark, you don't need me to remind you of your shortcomings. I would've thought by now they'd be obvious. C'mon, I'm starving and you're buying. And just in case you did miss the moral to the story, thank you, you should trust what's in people's hearts, not just the facts.
A lot of people have tried to get me on a couch and after all this time, I don't think I'm going to start with a psychiatrist.
And, guys, try not to let this place fall apart while I'm gone.
Yep, that's our Lois.
The genuine article.
I'm "colon" you back.
What'd ya open the door for?
I don't know. I thought maybe for a moment there, maybe... .
What? You were gonna stick your foot out and drag it along the street and stop the car?

[shrug]
Hmm.
You've been watching too many Flintstones cartoons.

If you don't mind my saying so, I think you have great legs. I think I read somewhere that intelligent men are leg-men. Only boobs are interested in, well, you know. Anyway, I think you have very shapely legs. They're like two perfectly-formed carrots.

[sarcastically]
Stop. You're embarrassing me.
[later... after kicking the bad guy]
You're right, Victor, I do have great legs.
Well, I think we've finally found the absolute bottom of Metropolis.
Why is it that the guys who call in with tips always live in the worst part of town?
What do you think the brochure on this place would say? Exquisite alley view, complimentary roaches on your pillow?
Clark, I don't want to die.
Lois, I would not let that happen.
I invented the word "hot-shot.'
I really do believe that we're all put here on this earth, or whatever planet we're put on, to do better than we think we can. To be kind, helpful, generous, and forgiving.
Why do you suppose someone would kidnap Bender?
Can't be for money. Who would pay ransom for a lawyer?
[talking about Lois and Clark's first date]
So you two excited?
Bobby, we didn't come here to talk about...
I want you to know how happy I am for you and that there are a lot of people out there that are really pulling for this to work out.
What people?
What, you think it's a big secret that Clark here has been mooning over you?
Well, I wouldn't say mooning exactly.
You were trying to say something and I... I...
Had a sudden urge to return a tape. It's perfectly understandable. I needed to express a deep personal feeling. You had to save three dollars.
Lois. You know, I really hope that someday you learn that sometimes what it seems like people are doing isn't really what they're doing.
What are you, a fortune cookie?
Are you all right?
You seem to ask me that a lot lately.
People try to kill you a lot.
Great shades of Elvis!
Don't threaten me, Doctor. You have no idea what I'm capable of.
They were pen pals.
They wrote to each other?
Heavens no! They met in the pen.
Jesse, it happens to every man once in a while.
Not to me.
Look, it's not your fault. His was just plain bigger.
Size never made no difference before.
You gotta get your mind off this, Jesse, or it could affect your future performance.
You know I could tell a lot about you from the way you organize your kitchen. I'm taking this course in applied psychology.
Sarah, I told you not to analyze me.
Oh, right. That's exactly what I would have said about you from the way you organize your kitchen.
Do you have a girlfriend right now?
Yes. No. It's kind of complicated. I haven't exactly told her everything about me, and I'm afraid that that is, well, it's making her drift toward this other guy.
Does he have superpowers too?

I just want one man. One whole man. Is that too much to ask for? And what do I have to chose from? I have one guy whose really wonderful, only he disappears every time I try and talk to him. And one guy whose really exciting to be with, only he won't talk to me about his work. What are people supposed to talk about if they won't talk about what they did all day? And one guy who is out of this world- - - literally.
I thought you'd given up the Superman fantasy?
My head has but you know, my heart is just... conflicted.
[talking about Clark]
Jonathan, of course he was acting odd, haven't you been listening to him? He's in love.
Threatening gifts... weird frogs... my fiance's typhoon fighting in India... It's not even 8 o'clock, what's next?
Lois, I'm not coming to your wedding.

[arriving at a crime scene after Superman and Lois, pulling a gun and pointing it at Superman]
Don't move!
New in town?
